parts.title: 📈 What is a graph? Why do we use it?
parts.description: Suppose you are riding a bicycle and measuring your speed. If you just say in words, “I was slow at first, then fast”, it’s a bit hard to understand. But if you draw a graph, you can see visually—when you were slow, when you were fast.

parts.content:
A graph means showing the relationship between two things as a picture. For example: time and speed, input and output.
📌 Why is a graph useful?
You can quickly see if something is increasing or decreasing.
You can see where the graph touches the axis.
Patterns, symmetry (mirror-like similarity), slope—these are easy to spot. So, it’s easier to predict what might happen in the future.

parts.questionText: Which of the following is a correct reason to use a graph?

options.text: To count numbers in a list
To understand the behavior of a function and make decisions
To see who can draw better

explanation.text: Graphs help to understand the behavior and patterns of functions.

parts.content:
🧠 Graph transformations — shifting, stretching, reflecting (Transformations)

Now we’ll learn how to shift, stretch, or reflect the graph of the same function—without calculation.

🔹 1. Horizontal Shift:
f(x − h): shifts h units to the right
f(x + h): shifts h units to the left
📌 Tip:
Think “minus means right”, “plus means left”.

options.text: A) Shifts 3 units to the left
B) Shifts 3 units to the right

parts.content:
🔹 2. Horizontal Stretch/Compression:
f(kx):
k > 1 → compressed (narrow)
0 < k < 1 → stretched (wide)

parts.questionText: Which of the following compresses the graph horizontally?

parts.content:
🎯 Final words:
Graph transformations (shift, stretch, reflect) don’t change the type of function, just its position or shape slightly.
This lets us quickly draw and understand graphs without calculation.
